channel.title: The edge of space
channel.description:
If you assume that we could go faster than the speed of light, and somehow managed to reach the end of space, what would happen when you got there. Would be similar to an invisible wall in a video game, where you simply cannot move anymore? If so, what would you see beyond the edge? Or would it be similar to being on the inside of a sphere? Or perhaps by the time you got to the edge, the universe has stopped expanding and it's just a wall and you crash and die? Maybe the universe has stopped expanding, and once you reach the edge, you actually pass through it, and are no longer considered "in existence" anymore?
I know that we'll never know what exactly happens if this was possible, but would do you think?

item.title: The edge of space
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

There is no edge. From every relative reference in space, space is expanding, leading to the conclusion that our universe is connected like the surface of a balloon. It may or may not be cleanly spherical, but it does form a bubble like membrane that is expanding outwards.

Read full topic

I lack huge amounts of knowledge on this topic but I think it could be that you just come out from another side.

item.title: The edge of space
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:1, topic:534186”]If you assume that we could go faster than the speed of light, and somehow managed to reach the end of space, what would happen when you got there. Would be similar to an invisible wall in a video game, where you simply cannot move anymore? If so, what would you see beyond the edge? Or would it be similar to being on the inside of a sphere? Or perhaps by the time you got to the edge, the universe has stopped expanding and it’s just a wall and you crash and die? Maybe the universe has stopped expanding, and once you reach the edge, you actually pass through it, and are no longer considered “in existence” anymore?

I know that we’ll never know what exactly happens if this was possible, but would do you think?[/quote]
Edge? What are you talking about?
I don’t believe there’s an edge, we’re just limited to our boxthinking. or however it’s called in english

Read full topic

item.title: The edge of space
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:12, topic:534186”][quote author=luna-scape link=topic=652980.msg4376118#msg4376118 date=1382078720]
I don’t think we could ever know this because our brains doesn’t work like that. I mean try thinking of a completely new color, it is impossible :o! It’s the same principal as thinking about what is at the ‘end’
[/quote]

I can pretty easily comprehend that “outside” the universe there is nothing, no space/time. (there technically is no “outside” the universe" just like there is no “before the big bang”).

It’s impossible to think of new colours not because of our brains, but because here are all that’s possible:
[/quote]
You forget that we can combine old colours to new colours.

Read full topic

item.title: The edge of space
item.dc:creator: @RS_From_The_00s RS From The 00s
item.description:
@RS_From_The_00s wrote:

I believe it’s very plausible we are a planet, within a solar system of planets, within a galaxy of solar systems, within a universe of galaxies, within a bubble of universes.

And universes can simply pop in and out of existence just like particles do (just over a larger scale of time).

I reckon if you reached the “edge” of the Universe it’d be like a game of Pacman. You’d pop out the opposite side.

Read full topic

item.title: The edge of space
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

If you accept the big bang theory then the universe is actually expanding faster then the speed of light. So is your definition of the edge of the universe the farthest point which light has traveled (some 14 billion years outwards from the big bang) or is it the point where the explosion from the big bang is still expanding to?

Either way if we got there I assume it would be cold as hell and desolate as fuck!

Read full topic

item.title: The edge of space
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

I assume there are three general topologies for the universe. One that has infinite space and time, one that has either finite space but infinite time or finite space and infinite time, or one that has finite time and space.

Read full topic
